Not all the individuals of a species are effective in the same way in the accumulation of toxins. The single individuals are usually selected from an old-time polluted environment, such as [[sludge]] or wastewater, where they had time to adapt to the circumstances, and the selection is carried on in the laboratory. A dilution of the water can drastically improve the ability of biosorption of the fungi.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Vaseem|first1=Huma|last2=Singh|first2=V. K.|last3=Singh|first3=M. P.|title=Heavy metal pollution due to coal washery effluent and its decontamination using a macrofungus, Pleurotus ostreatus|journal=Ecotoxicology and Environmental Safety|date=2017|volume=145|pages=42–49|doi=10.1016/j.ecoenv.2017.07.001|language=en|issn=1090-2414|pmid=28704692}}</ref>
The capacity of certain fungi to extract metals from the ground also can be useful for [[bioindicator]] purposes, and can be a problem when the mushroom is an edible one. For example, the shaggy ink cap (''[[Coprinus comatus]]''), a common edible north-hemisphere mushroom, can be a very good bioindicator of mercury, and accumulate it in its body, which can also be toxic to the consumer.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Falandysz|first1=Jerzy|title=Mercury bio-extraction by fungus Coprinus comatus: a possible bioindicator and mycoremediator of polluted soils?|journal=Environmental Science and Pollution Research International|date=2016|volume=23|issue=8|pages=7444–7451|doi=10.1007/s11356-015-5971-8|language=en|issn=1614-7499|quote=Eating them when foraged from the urban places can provide to a consumer Hg at relatively high dose, while unresolved question is absorption rate of Hg compounds contained in ingested mushroom meal.|pmid=26705753|pmc=4846694}}</ref>
The capacity of metals uptake of mushroom has also been used to recover precious metals from medium. [[VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland]] reported an 80% recovery of gold from [[electronic waste]] using [[mycofiltration]] techniques.<ref>[http://www.vttresearch.com/media/news/filter-developed-by-vtt-helps-recover-80-of-gold-in-mobile-phone-scrap]</ref>{{better source|date=December 2016}}
===Organic pollutants=== Fungi are amongst the primary [[saprotrophic]] organisms in an [[ecosystem]], as they are efficient in the [[decomposition]] of matter. [[Wood-decay fungus|Wood-decay fungi]], especially [[Wood-decay fungus#White rot|white rot]], secretes [[Fungal extracellular enzyme activity|extracellular enzymes]] and [[acid]]s that break down [[lignin]] and [[cellulose]], the two main building blocks of plant fiber. These are long-chain organic ([[carbon]]-based) compounds, structurally similar to many organic pollutants. They do so using a wide array of enzymes. In the case of [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons]] (PAHs), complex organic compounds with fused, highly stable, polycyclic [[aromatic ring]]s, fungi are very effective<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Batista-García|first1=Ramón Alberto|last2=Kumar|first2=Vaidyanathan Vinoth|last3=Ariste|first3=Arielle|last4=Tovar-Herrera|first4=Omar Eduardo|last5=Savary|first5=Olivier|last6=Peidro-Guzmán|first6=Heidy|last7=González-Abradelo|first7=Deborah|last8=Jackson|first8=Stephen A.|last9=Dobson|first9=Alan D. However, the same fungus substantially stimulated bacterial taxa that encompass putative PCB degraders.|pmid=27894756}}</ref>
=== Pesticides ===
[[Pesticide]] contamination can be long-term and have a significant impact on decomposition processes and thus nutrient cycling<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Magan|first1=Naresh|last2=Fragoeiro|first2=Silvia|last3=Bastos|first3=Catarina|title=Environmental Factors and Bioremediation of Xenobiotics Using White Rot Fungi|journal=Mycobiology|date=December 2010|volume=38|issue=4|pages=238–248|doi=10.4489/MYCO.2010.38.4.238|issn=1229-8093|pmc=3741516|pmid=23956663}}</ref> and their degradation can be expensive and difficult. The most used fungi for helping in the degradation of such substances are white rot ones which, thanks to their extracellular [[ligninolytic enzymes]] like [[laccase]] and [[manganese peroxidase]], are able to degrade high quantity of such components. Examples includes the [[insecticide]] [[endosulfan]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rivero|first1=Anisleidy|last2=Niell|first2=Silvina|last3=Cesio|first3=Verónica|last4=Cerdeiras|first4=M. Pía|last5=Heinzen|first5=Horacio|title=Analytical methodology for the study of endosulfan bioremediation under controlled conditions with white rot fungi|journal=Journal of Chromatography B|date=15 October 2012|volume=907|pages=168–172|doi=10.1016/j.jchromb.2012.09.010|language=en|issn=1873-376X|quote=the basidiomycete Bjerkandera adusta was able to degrade 83% of (alpha+beta) endosulfan after 27 days, 6 mg kg(-1) of endosulfan diol were determined; endosulfan ether and endosulfan sulfate were produced below 1 mg kg(-1) (LOQ, limit of quantitation).|pmid=23022115}}</ref> [[imazalil]], [[thiophanate methyl]], [[ortho-phenylphenol]], [[diphenylamine]], [[chlorpyrifos]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Karas|first1=Panagiotis A.|last2=Perruchon|first2=Chiara|last3=Exarhou|first3=Katerina|last4=Ehaliotis|first4=Constantinos|last5=Karpouzas|first5=Dimitrios G.|title=Potential for bioremediation of agro-industrial effluents with high loads of pesticides by selected fungi|journal=Biodegradation|date=2011|volume=22|issue=1|pages=215–228|doi=10.1007/s10532-010-9389-1|issn=1572-9729|pmid=20635121}}</ref> in wastewater, and [[atrazine]] in clay-loamy soils.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chan-Cupul|first1=Wilberth|last2=Heredia-Abarca|first2=Gabriela|last3=Rodríguez-Vázquez|first3=Refugio|title=Atrazine degradation by fungal co-culture enzyme extracts under different soil conditions|journal=Journal of Environmental Science and Health. Part. B, Pesticides, Food Contaminants, and Agricultural Wastes|date=2016|volume=51|issue=5|pages=298–308|doi=10.1080/03601234.2015.1128742|language=en|issn=1532-4109|quote=This study demonstrated that both the monoculture extracts of the native strain T. maxima and its co-culture with P. carneus can efficiently and quickly degrade atrazine in clay-loam soils.|pmid=26830051}}</ref>
=== Dyes ===
[[Dye]]s are used in many industries, like paper printing or textile. They are often recalcitant to degradation and in some cases, like some [[azo dyes]], [[cancerogenic]] or otherwise toxic.
The mechanism the fungi degrade this dyes is their lignolytic enzymes, especially laccase, so white rot mushrooms are the most commonly used.
Mycoremediation has proven to be a cheap and effective remediation technology for dyes such as [[malachite green]], [[nigrosin]] and [[basic fuchsin]] with ''[[Aspergillus niger]]'' and ''[[Phanerochaete chrysosporium]]''<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rani|first1=Babita|last2=Kumar|first2=Vivek|last3=Singh|first3=Jagvijay|last4=Bisht|first4=Sandeep|last5=Teotia|first5=Priyanku|last6=Sharma|first6=Shivesh|last7=Kela|first7=Ritu|title=Bioremediation of dyes by fungi isolated from contaminated dye effluent sites for bio-usability|journal=Brazilian Journal of Microbiology|date=9 October 2014|volume=45|issue=3|pages=1055–1063|language=en|issn=1517-8382|quote=Aspergillus niger recorded maximum decolorization of the dye Basic fuchsin (81.85%) followed by Nigrosin (77.47%), Malachite green (72.77%) and dye mixture (33.08%) under shaking condition. Whereas, P. chrysosporium recorded decolorization to the maximum with the Nigrosin (90.15%) followed by Basic fuchsin (89.8%), Malachite green (83.25%) and mixture (78.4%).|doi=10.1590/s1517-83822014000300039|pmc=4204947|pmid=25477943}}</ref> and [[Congo red]], a carcinogenic dye recalcitrant to biodegradative processes,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bhattacharya|first1=Sourav|last2=Das|first2=Arijit|last3=G|first3=Mangai|last4=K|first4=Vignesh|last5=J|first5=Sangeetha|title=Mycoremediation of congo red dye by filamentous fungi|journal=Brazilian Journal of Microbiology: [publication of the Brazilian Society for Microbiology]|date=2011|volume=42|issue=4|pages=1526–1536|doi=10.1590/S1517-838220110004000040|language=en|issn=1517-8382|quote=the decolourisation obtained at optimized conditions varied between 29.25- 97.28% at static condition and 82.1- 100% at shaking condition|pmid=24031787|pmc=3768715}}</ref> [[Direct Blue 14|direct blue 14]] (using ''Pleurotus'').<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Singh|first1=M. P.|last2=Vishwakarma|first2=S. K.|last3=Srivastava|first3=A. K.|title=Bioremediation of Direct Blue 14 and Extracellular Ligninolytic Enzyme Production by White Rot Fungi: Pleurotus Spp.|journal=BioMed Research International|date=2013|volume=2013|doi=10.1155/2013/180156|issn=2314-6133|pmc=3693104|pmid=23841054|pages=1–4}}</ref>
== Synergy with phytoremediation ==
[[Phytoremediation]] is the use of plant-based technologies to decontamination an area. Most of the plants can form a symbiosis with fungi, from which both the organisms get an advantage. This relationship is called [[mycorrhiza]].
Mycorrhizal fungi, especially [[arbuscular mycorrhiza|arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi]] (AMF), can greatly improve the phytoremediation capacity of some plants. This is mostly because the stress the plants suffer because of the pollutants is greatly reduced in presence of AMF, so they can grow more and produce more biomass.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rabie|first1=Gamal H.|title=Role of Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi in Phytoremediation of Soil Rhizosphere Spiked with Poly Aromatic Hydrocarbons|journal=Mycobiology|date=2005|volume=33|issue=1|pages=41–50|doi=10.4489/MYCO.2005.33.1.041|language=en|issn=1229-8093|quote=As consequence of the treatment with Am [Arbuscolar mycorrhize], the plants provide a greater sink for the contaminants since they are better able to survive and grow.|pmc=3774856|pmid=24049473}}</ref> The fungi also provide more nutrition, especially [[phosphorus]], and promotes the overall health of the plant. The mycelium quick expansion also can greatly extend the rhizosphere influenze zone ([[hyphosphere]]), providing the plant with access to more nutrients and contaminants.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rajtor|first1=Monika|last2=Piotrowska-Seget|first2=Zofia|title=Prospects for arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) to assist in phytoremediation of soil hydrocarbon contaminants|journal=Chemosphere|date=2016|volume=162|pages=105–116|doi=10.1016/j.chemosphere.2016.07.071|issn=1879-1298|quote=AMF have been considered to be a tool to enhance phytoremediation, as their mycelium create a widespread underground network that acts as a bridge between plant roots, soil and rhizosphere microorganisms. Abundant extramatrical hyphae extend the rhizosphere thus creating the hyphosphere, which significantly increases the area of a plant's access to nutrients and contaminants.|pmid=27487095}}</ref> Increasing the rhizosphere overall health also means a rise in the bacteria population, which can also contribute to the bioremediation process.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rabie|first1=Gamal H.|title=Role of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi in phytoremediation of soil rhizosphere spiked with poly aromatic hydrocarbons|journal=Mycobiology|date=2005|volume=33|issue=1|pages=41–50|doi=10.4489/MYCO.2005.33.1.041|issn=1229-8093|quote=Highly significant positive correlations were shown between of arbuscular formation in root segments (A)) and plant water content, root lipids, peroxidase, catalase polyphenol oxidase and total microbial count in soil rhizosphere as well as PAH dissipation in spiked soil.|pmid=24049473|pmc=3774856}}</ref>
This relationship has been proven useful with many pollutants, such as ''[[Rhizophagus intraradices]]'' and ''[[Robinia pseudoacacia]]'' in [[lead]] contaminated soil,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=Yurong|last2=Liang|first2=Yan|last3=Han|first3=Xiaozhen|last4=Chiu|first4=Tsan-Yu|last5=Ghosh|first5=Amit|last6=Chen|first6=Hui|last7=Tang|first7=Ming|title=The roles of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) in phytoremediation and tree-herb interactions in Pb contaminated soil|journal=Scientific Reports|date=4 February 2016|volume=6|doi=10.1038/srep20469|language=en|issn=2045-2322|quote=Non-mycorrhizal legumes were more sensitive to Pb addition than that of mycorrhizal legumes [...] The presence of AMF greatly increased the total biomass of legumes in all treatments,|pmc=4740888|pmid=26842958}}</ref> ''[[Rhizophagus intraradices]] ''with ''[[Glomus versiforme]] ''incoulated into vetiver grass for lead removal,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bahraminia|first1=Mahboobeh|last2=Zarei|first2=Mehdi|last3=Ronaghi|first3=Abdolmajid|last4=Ghasemi-Fasaei|first4=Reza|title=Effectiveness of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi in phytoremediation of lead- contaminated soil by vetiver grass|journal=International Journal of Phytoremediation|date=2016|volume=18|issue=7|pages=730–737|doi=10.1080/15226514.2015.1131242|language=en|issn=1549-7879|quote=With mycorrhizal inoculation and increasing Pb levels, Pb uptake of shoot and root increased compared to those of NM control|pmid=26709443}}</ref> AMF and ''[[Calendula officinalis]]'' in cadmium and lead contaminated soil,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tabrizi|first1=Leila|last2=Mohammadi|first2=Siavash|last3=Delshad|first3=Mojtaba|last4=Moteshare Zadeh|first4=Babak|title=Effect of Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi On Yield and Phytoremediation Performance of Pot Marigold (Calendula officinalis L.) Under Heavy Metals Stress|journal=International Journal of Phytoremediation|date=2015|volume=17|issue=12|pages=1244–1252|doi=10.1080/15226514.2015.1045131|language=en|issn=1549-7879|quote=However, mycorrhizal fungi alleviated these impacts by improving plant growth and yield. Pot marigold concentrated high amounts of Pb and especially Cd in its roots and shoots; mycorrhizal plants had a greater accumulation of these metals, so that those under 80 mg/kg Cd soil(-1) accumulated 833.3 and 1585.8 mg Cd in their shoots and roots, respectively.|pmid=26237494}}</ref> and in general was effective in increasing the plant bioremediation capacity for metals,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=Yurong|last2=Liang|first2=Yan|last3=Ghosh|first3=Amit|last4=Song|first4=Yingying|last5=Chen|first5=Hui|last6=Tang|first6=Ming|title=Assessment of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi status and heavy metal accumulation characteristics of tree species in a lead-zinc mine area: potential applications for phytoremediation|journal=Environmental Science and Pollution Research International|date=2015|volume=22|issue=17|pages=13179–13193|doi=10.1007/s11356-015-4521-8|issn=1614-7499|quote=Redundancy analysis (RDA) showed that the efficiency of phytoremediation was enhanced by AM symbioses, and soil pH, Pb, Zn, and Cd levels were the main factors influencing the HM accumulation characteristics of plants.|pmid=25929455}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Li|first1=Shao-Peng|last2=Bi|first2=Yin-Li|last3=Kong|first3=Wei-Ping|last4=Wang|first4=Jin|last5=Yu|first5=Hai-Yang|title=[Effects of the arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on environmental phytoremediation in coal mine areas]|journal=Huan Jing Ke Xue= Huanjing Kexue|date=2013|volume=34|issue=11|pages=4455–4459|language=en|issn=0250-3301|quote=Population of microorganism increased obviously. All the above results show that their ecological effects are significantly improved. AM would promote rhizosphere soil that will help the sustainability of ecological systems in mining area.|pmid=24455959}}</ref> petroleum fuels,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Xun|first1=Feifei|last2=Xie|first2=Baoming|last3=Liu|first3=Shasha|last4=Guo|first4=Changhong|title=Effect of plant growth-promoting bacteria (PGPR) and arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) inoculation on oats in saline-alkali soil contaminated by petroleum to enhance phytoremediation|journal=Environmental Science and Pollution Research International|date=2014|volume=22|issue=1|pages=598–608|doi=10.1007/s11356-014-3396-4|language=en|issn=1614-7499|quote=the degradation rate of total petroleum hydrocarbon during treatment with PGPR and AMF in moderately contaminated soil reached a maximum of 49.73%|pmid=25091168}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hernández-Ortega|first1=Herminia Alejandra|last2=Alarcón|first2=Alejandro|last3=Ferrera-Cerrato|first3=Ronald|last4=Zavaleta-Mancera|first4=Hilda Araceli|last5=López-Delgado|first5=Humberto Antonio|last6=Mendoza-López|first6=Ma Remedios|title=Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on growth, nutrient status, and total antioxidant activity of Melilotus albus during phytoremediation of a diesel-contaminated substrate|journal=Journal of Environmental Management|date=2012|volume=95 Suppl|pages=S319–324|doi=10.1016/j.jenvman.2011.02.015|language=en|issn=1095-8630|quote=AMF-plants significantly contributed in higher degradation of total petroleum hydrocarbons when compared to non-AMF-plants.|pmid=21420227}}</ref> and PAHs.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rabie|first1=Gamal H.|title=Role of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi in phytoremediation of soil rhizosphere spiked with poly aromatic hydrocarbons|journal=Mycobiology|date=2005|volume=33|issue=1|pages=41–50|doi=10.4489/MYCO.2005.33.1.041|issn=1229-8093|quote=Highly significant positive correlations were shown between of arbuscular formation in root segments (A)) and plant water content, root lipids, peroxidase, catalase polyphenol oxidase and total microbial count in soil rhizosphere as well as PAH dissipation in spiked soil.|pmid=24049473|pmc=3774856}}</ref> In wetlands AMF greatly promote the biodegradation of organic pollutants like benzene-, methyl tert-butyl ether- and ammonia from groundwater when inoculated into ''[[Phragmites australis]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fester|first1=Thomas|title=Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi in a wetland constructed for benzene-, methyl tert-butyl ether- and ammonia-contaminated groundwater bioremediation|journal=Microbial Biotechnology|date=1 January 2013|volume=6|issue=1|pages=80–84|doi=10.1111/j.1751-7915.2012.00357.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1751-7915.2012.00357.x/full|accessdate=26 September 2017|language=en|issn=1751-7915}}</ref>

[[File:Robert Blinc 1969.jpg|thumbnail|Robert Blinc in 1969]] '''Robert Blinc''' (October 31, 1933 – September 26, 2011<ref name="sazu.si">[http://www.sazu.si/o-sazu/clani/robert-blinc.html Blinc, Robert - Slovenska Akademija Znanosti in Umetnosti - sazu.si<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>) was a prominent [[Slovenes|Slovene]] [[physicist]].
He completed his undergraduate studies in 1958 at the Faculty of Natural Sciences in Ljubljana and received a [[PhD]] a year later. He then started post-doc study at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]. When he returned to Slovenia, he continued his work at the [[Jožef Stefan Institute]]. He became a [[professor]] at the [[University of Ljubljana]] in 1970. He was the first Dean of [[Jožef Stefan International Postgraduate School]] in Ljubljana since 2004.
Professor Blinc was one of the founders of uses of [[nuclear magnetic resonance]] for investigations of [[phase transition]]s and [[liquid crystals]].<ref name="sazu.si"/> He established NMR/EPR spectroscopy in Slovenia (his first paper on the subject was published in early 1958) and was the head of the Condensed Matter Physics Department at the [[Jožef Stefan Institute]].<ref name="ijs.si">[http://www.ijs.si/ The Jožef Stefan Institute homepage]</ref> He was the president of AMPERE Groupement for two mandates during 1990–1996. He was a member of the [[Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts]] and served as its vice president from October 2, 1980 to May 6, 1999. He was also a member of the [[European Academy of Sciences and Arts]] and an honorary member of the [[Society of Mathematicians, Physicists and Astronomers of Slovenia]].<ref name="sazu.si"/> He died in [[Ljubljana]], [[Slovenia]].

at the confluence of three constituent partsAdams, W.M. (2006). [http://cmsdata.iucn.org/downloads/iucn_future_of_sustanability.pdf "The Future of Sustainability: Re-thinking Environment and Development in the Twenty-first Century."] Report of the IUCN Renowned Thinkers Meeting, 29–31 January 2006. Retrieved on: 2009-02-16.}} [[File:Circles of Sustainability image (assessment - Melbourne 2011).jpg|250px|thumb|The four domains of social sustainability according to the [[Circles of Sustainability]] approach used by the [[United Nations Global Compact|United Nations]]http://citiesprogramme.com/archives/resource/circles-of-sustainability-urban-profile-process {{Cite journal | year=2013 |author1=Liam Magee |author2=Andy Scerri |author3=Paul James |author4=James A. Thom |author5=Lin Padgham |author6=Sarah Hickmott |author7=Hepu Deng |author8=Felicity Cahill | title=Reframing social sustainability reporting: Towards an engaged approach | url=https://www.academia.edu/4362669/Reframing_Social_Sustainability_Reporting_Towards_an_Engaged_Approach | journal=Environment, Development and Sustainability }} ]] '''Social life''' is the least defined and least understood of the different ways of approaching [[sustainability]] and [[sustainable development]]. Social sustainability has had considerably less attention in public dialogue than economic and environmental sustainability. There are several approaches to sustainability. The first, which posits a triad of environmental sustainability, [[economic sustainability]], and social sustainability, is the most widely accepted as a model for addressing sustainability. The concept of "social sustainability" in this approach encompasses such topics as: [[social equity]], [[livability]], [[health equity]], [[community development]], [[social capital]], [[social support]], [[human rights]], [[labour rights]], [[placemaking]], [[social responsibility]], [[social justice]], [[cultural competence]], community resilience, and human adaptation. A second, more recent, approach suggests that all of the domains of sustainability are social: including ecological, economic, political and cultural sustainability. These domains of social sustainability are all dependent upon the relationship between the social and the natural, with the "ecological domain" defined as human embeddedness in the environment. In these terms, social sustainability encompasses all human activities.{{Cite book | last1= James | first1= Paul | authorlink= Paul James (academic) | last2= with Magee | first2= Liam | last3= Scerri | first3= Andy | last4= Steger | first4= Manfred B. | title= Urban Sustainability in Theory and Practice: Circles of Sustainability | url= https://www.academia.edu/9294719/Urban_Sustainability_in_Theory_and_Practice_Circles_of_Sustainability_2015_ | year= 2015 | publisher= Routledge | location= London}} It is not just relevant to the focussed intersection of economics, the environment and the social.{{Cite journal | year=2013 |author1=Liam Magee |author2=Andy Scerri |author3=Paul James |author4=James A. Thom |author5=Lin Padgham |author6=Sarah Hickmott |author7=Hepu Deng |author8=Felicity Cahill | title= Reframing social sustainability reporting: Towards an engaged approach | url= https://www.academia.edu/4362669/Reframing_Social_Sustainability_Reporting_Towards_an_Engaged_Approach | journal= Environment, Development and Sustainability }} (See the Venn diagram and the [[Circles of Sustainability]] diagram). ==Definitions== According to the Western Australia Council of Social Services (WACOSS):[http://auspsa.anu.edu.au/proceedings/publications/Partridgepaper.pdf] ''"Social sustainability occurs when the formal and informal processes; systems; structures; and relationships actively support the capacity of current and future generations to create healthy and liveable communities. Socially sustainable communities are equitable, diverse, connected and democratic and provide a good quality of life."'' Another definition has been developed by Social Life,[http://www.social-life.co/ http://www.social-life.co] a UK-based social enterprise specialising in place-based innovation. They define social sustainability as "''a process for creating sustainable, successful places that promote wellbeing, by understanding what people need from the places they live and work. Social sustainability combines design of the physical realm with design of the social world – infrastructure to support social and cultural life, social amenities, systems for citizen engagement and space for people and places to evolve''."[http://www.social-life.co/media/files/DESIGN_FOR_SOCIAL_SUSTAINABILITY_3.pdf S.Woodcraft et al (2011) Design for Social Sustainability, Social Life, London] ==Dimensions== Social Life have developed a framework for social sustainability[http://www.social-life.co/publication/Social-Sustainability/] which has four dimensions: amenities and infrastructure, social and cultural life, voice and influence, and space to grow. Nobel Laureate [[Amartya Sen]] gives the following dimensions for social sustainability:[http://integral-sustainability.net/wp-content/uploads/sas4-2-hodgson.pdf] *'''Equity''' - the community provides equitable opportunities and outcomes for all its members, particularly the poorest and most vulnerable members of the community *'''Diversity''' - the community promotes and encourages diversity *'''Interconnected/Social cohesions''' - the community provides processes, systems and structures that promote connectedness within and outside the community at the formal, informal and institutional level *'''Quality of life''' - the community ensures that basic needs are met and fosters a good quality of life for all members at the individual, group and community level (e.g. health, housing, education, employment, safety) *'''Democracy and governance''' - the community provides democratic processes and open and accountable governance structures. *'''Maturity''' - the individual accept the responsibility of consistent growth and improvement through broader social attributes (e.g. communication styles, behavioural patterns, indirect education and philosophical explorations) Also we can speak of Sustainable Human Development that can be seen as development that promotes the capabilities of present people without compromising capabilities of future generations.Sen, A.K. (2000) ‘The ends and means of sustainability’, keynote address at the International Conference on Transition to sustainability, Tokyo, May In the human development paradigm, environment and natural resources should constitute a means of achieving better standards of living just as income represents a means of increasing social expenditure and, in the end, well-being.Anand, S. and Sen, A.K. (1996) ‘Sustainable human development: concepts and priorities’, Office of Development Studies Discussion Paper, No. 1, UNDP, New York The different aspects of social sustainability are often considered in [[socially responsible investing]] (SRI). Social sustainability criteria that are commonly used by SRI funds and indexes to rate publicly traded companies include: community, diversity, employee relations, human rights, product safety, reporting, and governance structure.KLD Research. Environmental, Social and Governance Rating Criteria. 2007The Combined Code on Corporate Governance, June 2008 {{Library resources box |others=yes |lcheading=Sustainable development--Social aspects }} == Application and Verification == The [[United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights|UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights]] state that countries have the obligation to “respect, protect, and fulfill human rights and fundamental freedoms” and that business enterprises are required to comply with all applicable laws and respect human rights.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Publications/GuidingPrinciplesBusinessHR_EN.pdf|title=Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights|last=United Nations Human Rights, Office of the Commissioner|first=|date=|website=|publisher=United Nations, New York and Geneva|access-date=10 March 2016}} Both production and procurement of goods and services should be documented to verify satisfaction of these international principles and laws.{{Cite web|url=https://sftool.gov/plan/541/verifying-delivery-sustainable-products-services|title=Verifying Delivery of Sustainable Products and Services - GSA Sustainable Facilities Tool|website=sftool.gov|access-date=2016-03-10}} The UN Guiding Principles also include a reporting framework,{{Cite web|url=http://www.ungpreporting.org/|title=UN Guiding Principles Reporting Framework|website=www.ungpreporting.org|access-date=2016-03-10}} which teaches companies how to report their interaction with human rights issues. In addition resources like Free2Work,[http://www.free2work.org/ Free2Work] the [[Global Reporting Initiative]], and [http://business-humanrights.org/ Business and Human Rights Resource Centre] all provide information on organizational disclosures and performance in social sustainability.{{Cite web|url=https://sftool.gov/plan/545/social-sustainability|title=Social Sustainability - GSA Sustainable Facilities Tool|website=sftool.gov|access-date=2016-03-10}} Certifications from internationally recognized and accredited organizations are available to aid in verifying the social sustainability of products and services. The [[Forest Stewardship Council]] (paper and forest products),[http://www.cocoainitiative.org/en/ International Cocoa Initiative] and [[Kimberley Process Certification Scheme|Kimberly Process]] (diamonds) are examples of such organizations and initiatives.{{Cite web|url=https://sftool.gov/plan/546/social-sustainability-initiatives-guidelines-standards|title=Social Sustainability Initiatives, Guidelines, and Standards - GSA Sustainable Facilities Tool|website=sftool.gov|access-date=2016-03-10}} ==See also== {{Portal|Sustainable development}} * [[Circles of Sustainability]] * [[Sustainable development]] * [[Sustainability]] * [[Sustainable business]] * [[Socially responsible investing]] ===Notes=== {{reflist}} ==References== * Hicks, 1997 D.A. {{italic title}} '''''The Dorito Effect: The Surprising New Truth about Food and Flavor''''', by Mark Schatzker, is a book about two detrimental trends in modern [[food culture]]. The pursuit of maximum monetary gain by means of increased yield and [[pest resistance]] has involved the neglect of flavor in the [[Selective breeding|breeding]] process. On the other hand, to provide the flavor missing from [[industrialized food]], [[food processing|food processors]] add [[flavor]]s which fool the body into believing that it is receiving the necessary [[nutrient]]s. The book was published in 2015 by [[Simon & Schuster]].
==External links== *[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/food-and-wine/food-trends/the-flavour-factor-undoing-the-dorito-effect/article24151856/ ''The Dorito Effect'': How our approach to food is killing its flavour]—''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' (April 28, 2015) *[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/14/books/review/the-dorito-effect-by-mark-schatzker.html?_r=0 ''The Dorito Effect,'' by Mark Schatzker]—''[[The New York Times]]'' (June 12, 2015) *[http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/22609354-the-dorito-effect ''The Dorito Effect: The Surprising New Truth About Food and Flavor'']—[[Goodreads]]

The '''thermal Hall effect''' is the thermal analog of the [[Hall effect]]. Here, a thermal gradient is produced across a solid instead of an electric field. When a magnetic field is applied, an orthogonal temperature gradient develops.
For [[conductor (material)|conductors]], a significant portion of the thermal current is carried by the electrons. In particular, the '''Righi–Leduc effect'''<ref>After the Italian physicist [[Augusto Righi]] (1850–1920) and the French physicist [[Sylvestre Anatole Leduc]] (1856–1937), see: {{cite book | last=Lalena |first=John N. |last2=Cleary |first2=David A. | year=2010 | page=272 | title=Principles of Inorganic Materials Design | edition=2nd | publisher=John Wiley and Sons | isbn=0-470-40403-5 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vsd45oIxZ24C&pg=PA272 | accessdate=2011-04-25 }}</ref> describes the heat flow resulting from a perpendicular temperature gradient and vice versa, and the '''Maggi–Righi–Leduc effect''' describes changes in [[thermal conductivity]] when placing a conductor in a [[magnetic field]].
A thermal Hall effect has also been measured in a paramagnetic ''insulator'' and called the "phonon Hall effect".<ref name="Strohm">{{cite journal | last = Strohm | first = Cornelius | first2=Geert L. J. A. |last2=Rikken |first3=Peter |last3=Wyder | date = October 7, 2005 | title = Phenomenological Evidence for the Phonon Hall Effect | journal = Physical Review Letters | volume = 95 | pages = 155901 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.95.155901 | url = http://scitation.aip.org/getabs/servlet/GetabsServlet?prog=normal&id=PRLTAO000095000015155901000001&idtype=cvips&gifs=yes&citing=all | pmid = 16241740 | issue = 15 | bibcode=2005PhRvL..95o5901S}}</ref> In this case, there are no charged currents in the solid, so the magnetic field cannot exert a [[Lorentz force]]. An analogous thermal Hall effect for neutral particles exists in polyatomic gases (known as the [[Senftleben–Beenakker effect]]).
Measurements of the thermal Hall conductivity are used to distinguish between the electronic and lattice contributions to thermal conductivity. These measurements are especially useful when studying [[superconductors]].
== See also == * [[Hall effect]]

{{Use dmy dates |date=October 2013}} [[File:Letharia vulpina closeup.jpg|thumb|upright|''[[Letharia vulpina]]'', one of the species of lichen credited with having a cancer-inhibiting molecule in a fake manuscript.<ref name="bohannon"/>]] "'''Who's Afraid of Peer Review?'''" is an article written by [[Science (journal)|''Science'']] correspondent [[John Bohannon]] that describes his investigation of [[peer review]] among [[Open access journal#Fee-based open access journals|fee-charging open-access journals]]. Between January and August 2013, Bohannon submitted fake scientific papers to 304 journals owned by as many fee-charging open access publishers. The papers, writes Bohannon, "were designed with such grave and obvious scientific flaws that they should have been rejected immediately by editors and peer reviewers", but 60% of the journals accepted them. The article and associated data were published in the 4 October 2013 issue of ''Science'' as open access.<ref name="bohannon60"/><ref name="Who's Afraid of Peer Review: Data and Documents"/>
==Background== The first fee-charging open access scientific journals began appearing in 2000 with the creation of [[BioMed Central]] and then the [[Plos|Public Library of Science]]. Rather than deriving at least some of their revenue from subscription fees, fee-charging open access journals only charge the authors (or their funders) a [[Article Processing Charge|publication fee]]. The published papers are then freely available on the internet. This business model, [[gold open access]], is one of several solutions devised to make open access publishing sustainable.<ref name="Open Access Overview"/> The number of articles published open access, or made freely available after some time behind a paywall ([[delayed open access journal|delayed open access]]), has grown rapidly. In 2013 more than half of the scientific papers published in 2011 were available for free.<ref name="Half of 2011 papers now free to read"/>
In part because of the low barrier to entry into this market, as well as the fast and potentially large return on investment, many so-called "[[Predatory open access publishing|predatory publishers]]" have created low-quality journals that provide little to no peer review or editorial control, essentially publishing every submitted article as long as the publication fee is paid. Some of these publishers additionally deceive authors about publication fees, use the names of scientists as editors and reviewers without their knowledge, and/or obfuscate the true location and identity of the publishers.<ref name="Some Online Journals Will Publish Fake Science, For A Fee"/> The prevalence of these deceptive publishers, and what the [[scientific community]] should do about them, has been hotly debated.<ref name="Investigating journals: The dark side of publishing"/>
==Methods==
===Fake papers=== Bohannon used [[Python (programming language)|Python]] to create a "scientific version of [[Mad Libs]]".<ref name="bohannon60"/><ref name="Inside Science Magazine's 'Sting' of Open Access Journals"/> The paper's template is "Molecule X from [[lichen]] species Y inhibits the growth of cancer cell Z". He created a database of molecules, lichens, and cancer cells to substitute for X, Y, and Z. The data and conclusions were identical in every paper. The authors and their affiliations were also unique, and fake. The papers all described the discovery of a new cancer drug extracted from a lichen, but the data did not support that conclusion and the papers had intentionally obvious flaws.<ref name="Science's Sokal moment"/><ref name="Fake Cancer Study Spotlights Bogus Science Journals"/>
===Publisher targets=== To build a comprehensive list of fee-charging open access publishers, Bohannon relied on two sources: [[Beall's List]] of predatory publishers and the [[Directory of Open Access Journals]] (DOAJ). After filtering both lists for open access journals published in English, that charge authors a publication fee, and that have at least one medical, biological, or chemical journal, the list of targets included 304 publishers: 167 from the DOAJ, 121 from Beall's list, and 16 that were listed by both. The investigation focused entirely on fee-charging open access journals. Bohannon did not include other types of open access journals or subscription journals for comparison because the turnaround time for reviews in traditional journals is too long. The study consequently makes no claim about the relative quality of the different types of journals.<ref name="Science reporter spoofs hundreds of open access journals with fake papers"/>
==Results==
===Acceptance versus rejection=== In total, 157 of the journals accepted the paper and 98 rejected it, with the other 49 not having completed their evaluation by the time Bohannon wrote his article.<ref name="bohannon60"/> Of the 255 papers that underwent the entire peer review process to acceptance or rejection, about 60% of the final decisions occurred with no sign of actual peer review. For rejections, that may possibly have reflected filtering at the editorial level, but for acceptance can only reflect a flawed process. Only 36 submissions generated review comments recognizing any of the paper's scientific problems. 16 of those 36 papers were nonetheless accepted, in spite of poor to damning reviews. Many of the journals that accepted the paper are published by prestigious institutions and publishing companies, including [[Elsevier#Who's Afraid of Peer Review|Elsevier]], [[Sage Publications|Sage]], [[Wolters Kluwer]] (through its subsidiary [[Medknow Publications|Medknow]]), and several universities.<ref name="bohannon60"/>
Among those that rejected the paper are journals published by [[Public Library of Science|PLOS]], [[BioMed Central]], and [[Hindawi Publishing Corporation|Hindawi]]. The peer review provided by ''[[PLOS ONE]]'' was reported to be the most rigorous of all, and it was the only journal that identified the paper's [[Research ethics|ethical problems]], for example the lack of documentation of how [[animal testing|animals were treated]] in the creation of the cancer cell lines.<ref name="bohannon60"/>
===DOAJ versus Beall's list=== Among the publishers on Beall's list that completed the review process, 82% accepted the paper. Bohannon stated "the results show that Beall is good at spotting publishers with poor quality control". According to [[Jeffrey Beall]], who created the list, this supports his claim to be identifying "predatory" publishers.<ref name="Science Magazine Conducts Sting Operation on OA Publishers"/> However, the remaining 18% of publishers identified by Beall as predatory rejected the fake paper, leading [[Science communication|science communicator]] Phil Davis to state "That means that Beall is falsely accusing nearly one in five".<ref name=Davis>{{cite web |last1=Davis |first1=Phil |url=http://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2013/10/04/open-access-sting-reveals-deception-missed-opportunities/|title=Open Access "Sting" Reveals Deception, Missed Opportunities |work=[[The Scholarly Kitchen]]}}</ref>
Among the DOAJ publishers that completed the review process, 45% accepted the paper.<ref name=Davis /> According to a statement published on the DOAJ website, new criteria for inclusion in the DOAJ are being implemented.<ref name="doaj"/>
===Global map of journal fraud=== Along with the report, ''Science'' published a map that shows the location of publishers, editors, and their bank accounts, color-coded by acceptance or rejection of the paper. The locations were derived from IP address traces within the raw headers of e-mails, [[WHOIS]] registrations, and bank invoices for publication fees. India emerged as the world's largest base for fee-charging open-access publishing, with 64 accepting the fatally flawed papers and only 15 rejecting it.<ref name="bohannon60" /> The United States is the next largest base, with 29 publishers accepting the paper and 26 rejecting it. In Africa, Nigeria has the largest number, of which 100% accepted the paper.<ref name="Peer review map"/>
==Responses==
===Responses from the open-access academic publishing industry=== Since the story was released, publishers of three journals have stated that they are shutting them down.<ref name="Fallout from Science's publisher sting: Journal closes in Croatia"/> The DOAJ is reviewing its list and instituting tighter criteria for inclusion.<ref name="Second response to the Bohannon article"/> The [[Open Access Scholarly Publishers Association]] (OASPA) formed a committee to investigate the circumstances that led to the acceptance of the fake paper by three of its members.<ref name="redhead"/> On 11 November 2013, OASPA terminated the membership of two publishers ([[Dove Medical Press]] and Hikari Ltd.) who accepted the fake paper. Sage Publications, which also accepted a fake paper, was put "under review" for 6 months.<ref name="oaspa"/> Sage announced in a statement that it was reviewing the journal that accepted the fake paper, but that it would not shut it down.<ref name="Statement by SAGE on the Journal of International Medical Research"/> Sage's membership was reinstated at the end of the review period following changes to the journal's editorial processes.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shaffi |first=Sarah |url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/oaspa-reinstates-sage-membership.html|title=OASPA reinstates Sage membership |work=[[The Bookseller]] |date=29 April 2014|accessdate=2 June 2014}}</ref>
===Responses from the scientific community=== Within hours of its publication, the ''Science'' investigation came under intense criticism by some supporters of the open-access movement.<ref name="Critics Say Sting on Open-Access Journals Misses Larger Point"/><ref name="Post Open Access Sting: An Interview With John Bohannon"/>
The first substantial critique was posted by PLOS cofounder Michael Eisen on his blog. "To suggest – as ''Science'' (though not Bohannon) are trying to do – that the problem with scientific publishing is that open access enables internet scamming is like saying that the problem with the international finance system is that it enables Nigerian wire transfer scams. There are deep problems with science publishing. But the way to fix this is not to curtail open-access publishing. It is to fix peer review."<ref name="I confess, I wrote the Arsenic DNA paper to expose flaws in peer-review at subscription based journals"/> Eisen pointed out the irony of a subscription-based journal like ''Science'' publishing this report when its own peer review has failed so badly before, as in the 2010 publication of the [[GFAJ-1|arsenic DNA paper]].
In an exchange between Eisen and Bohannon in a discussion hosted by [[Peter Suber]], director of the Harvard Open Access Project, Eisen criticized the investigation for the bad publicity it generated for the open-access movement.<ref name="google"/> "Your study exclusively targeted open access journals – [which] strongly suggested, whether you meant to suggest this or not, that open access journals are more likely to engage in shoddy peer review and therefore more deserving of scrutiny." Bohannon responded that this critique was equivalent to "[[shooting the messenger]]".
There have also been many statements of support for the investigation,<ref name="Research paper publishing sting reveals lax standards of many open-access journals"/><ref name="davis"/> and statements of concern about the publishing fraud that it revealed.<ref name="Sting exposes 'wild west' of open-access publishing"/><ref name="Dubious journal fear stalks India"/><ref name="Lessons from the faux journal investigation"/> The [[Committee on Publication Ethics]] has responded that "There is no doubt that this 'sting' raises a number of issues ... though I'd argue they are not necessarily the ones that ''Science'' thinks are top priorities."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://publicationethics.org/news/cope-response-science-paper-submission-fake-paper-virginia-barbour-behalf-cope-council|title=COPE response to Science paper submission of fake paper, by Virginia Barbour, on behalf of COPE council|publisher=}}</ref>
==Implications== Some scientists have discussed a number of options for making [[Open peer review|peer review more transparent]].<ref name="Transparency in peer review"/> Doing so would make it harder to maintain a predatory journal that does no peer review, because the record of peer review would be lacking or would need to be faked.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/information-culture/2014/11/26/is-this-peer-reviewed-predatory-journals-and-the-transparency-of-peer-review/|title=Is this peer reviewed? Predatory journals and the transparency of peer review.|publisher=}}</ref> Another option is to more rigorously vet journals, for example by further empowering DOAJ or OASPA. DOAJ has recently tightened up its inclusion criteria, with the purpose of serving as a [[whitelist]], very much like [[Predatory journal|Beall's]] has been a [[blacklist]].<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/512017a| title = Open-access website gets tough| journal = Nature| volume = 512| issue = 7512| pages = 17| year = 2014| last1 = Van Noorden | first1 = R.| pmid=25100463}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Sting operation]] * [[Sokal affair]] * [[SCIgen]] * ''[[International Journal of Advanced Computer Technology]]'' * [[List of scholarly publishing hoaxes]]

[[Image:William Gurley Lithograph.JPG|right|thumb]] '''William Gurley''' (March 16, 1821 – January 11, 1887) co-founded what is now known as [[Gurley Precision Instruments]] with his brother, and served as vice president and, from 1886 to 1887, acting president of [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]].
Gurley was born in [[Troy, New York]], March 16, 1821, the son of Ephraim and Clarissa (Sharp) Gurley. He received the best education afforded by the schools in this vicinity, and choosing the profession of a civil engineer, attended the [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]], from which he graduated in 1839. He worked as a surveyor for a few years and then joined the firm of Oscar Hanks, who was a well-known maker of surveying instruments and church bells in Troy. He worked for Hanks for five years.
In 1845, Gurley established his own scientific instrument manufacturing business in partnership with James Phelps.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.nysl.nysed.gov/msscfa/sc21620.htm|title = Gurley Family Papers, 1862-1915 (finding aid)|date = |access-date = 22 Feb 2016|website = New York State Library Website|publisher = [[New York State Library]]|last = |first = }}</ref> Phelps had had his own shop since 1838. They called the business Phelps & Gurley. In 1844, William Gurley's brother Lewis Ephraim Gurley joined Phelps' shop as an apprentice and he then attended [[Union College]] from 1847 to 1851. Lewis Gurley rejoined the firm in 1851, at which point it was renamed Phelps and Gurleys. In 1852, Phelps sold out his interest and the business was renamed W.& L.E. Gurley. The firm still exists today as [[Gurley Precision Instruments]]. William Gurley was involved in several local organizations. For many years he was connected with the [[YMCA]], and in 1851 was elected its president. He served as [[alderman]] from 1860 to 1864, and as fire commissioner he helped to improve fire prevention systems in major cities. He was a member of the [[New York State Assembly]] (Rensselaer Co., 1st D.) in [[90th New York State Legislature|1867]]. In 1868, he was appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury to serve on a commission with Prof. [[Joseph Henry]] and other scientific experts to examine the best meter devised for determining the products of distillation, to be subsequently adopted by the department.
Gurley was a long-time trustee of [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute|Rensselaer]], having been elected to that position in 1855. He was secretary of the institution from 1861 to 1872, vice-president from 1872 to 1887 and acting president from 1886 to 1887. He died on January 11, 1887 in Troy.
The [[W. & L. E. Gurley Building]] in Troy was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1983.

[[File:World Psychiatric Association regional congress 2014A.jpg|thumb|World Psychiatric Association regional congress 2014]] The '''World Psychiatric Association''' is an international umbrella organisation of psychiatric societies.
== Objectives and goals == Originally created to produce world psychiatric congresses, it has evolved to hold regional meetings, to promote professional education and to set ethical, scientific and treatment standards for [[psychiatry]].
== History == [[Jean Delay]] was the first president of the Association for the Organization of World Congresses of Psychiatry when it was started in 1950.<ref name=history>{{cite web |title=History of the World Psychiatric Association |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://www.wpanet.org/detail.php?section_id=5&content_id=44 |access-date=26 December 2016 }}</ref> [[Donald Ewen Cameron]] became president of the World Psychiatric Association at its formal founding in 1961.<ref name=history/><ref name=chronology/>
In February 1983, the Soviet All-Union Society of Neurologists and Psychiatrists resigned from the World Psychiatric Association. This resignation occurred as a preemptive action amid a movement to expel the Soviet body from the global organization due to [[political abuse of psychiatry in the Soviet Union]].<ref>Vera Rich, [https://www.nature.com/articles/301559a0.pdf Soviet psychiatry: pre-emptive resignation?], ''Nature'' (February 17, 1983).</ref><ref>Allan Wynn, [https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(83)91514-3/abstract The Soviet Union and the World Psychiatric Association], ''The Lancet'' (February 19, 1983).</ref> The Soviet body was conditionally readmitted into the World Psychiatric Association in 1989, following some improvements in human rights conditions,<ref>Masha Hamilton, [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-04-02/news/mn-1416_1_amnesty-international Soviets Win Praise From Amnesty International], ''Los Angeles Times'' (April 2, 1989).</ref> and an intensive debate among the association's delegates, in which the acting secretary of the Soviet delegation issued a statement conceding that "previous political conditions in the U.S.S.R. created an environment in which psychiatric abuse occurred, including for nonmedical reasons."<ref>Paul Anastasi, [https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/18/world/soviets-conditionally-readmitted-to-world-psychiatric-association.html Soviets Conditionally Readmitted To World Psychiatric Association], ''New York Times'' (October 18, 1989).</ref>
{{As of|2017|post=,}} [[Helen Herrman]] is president, and Afzal Javed is president-elect.<ref name=executive>{{cite web |title=The Executive Committee |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://www.wpanet.org/detail.php?section_id=5&content_id=46 |access-date=27 December 2017 }}</ref>

== Structure == {{As of|2016|post=,}} the institutional members of the World Psychiatric Association are 138 national psychiatric societies in 118 countries representing more than 200,000 psychiatrists worldwide.<ref name=about>{{cite web |title= About the World Psychiatric Association |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://www.wpanet.org/detail.php?section_id=5&content_id=4 |access-date=24 December 2016 }}</ref> The societies are clustered into 18 zones and four regions: the Americas, Europe, Africa & Middle East, and Asia & Australasia.<ref name=bylaws2011>{{cite web |title=World Psychiatric Association (WPA) By-laws |date=21 September 2011 |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://wpanet.org/uploads/About_WPA/Statutes_and_Bylaws/WPA%20By-Laws%202011%20-%20Amended.pdf |format=PDF }}</ref> Representatives of the societies constitute the World Psychiatric Association General Assembly, the governing body of the organization.<ref name=bylaws2011/><ref name=Statutes2011>{{cite web |title=World Psychiatric Association (WPA) Statutes |date=21 September 2011 |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://wpanet.org/uploads/About_WPA/Statutes_and_Bylaws/WPA%20Statutes%202011.pdf |format=PDF }}</ref> The association also has individual members and there are provisions for affiliation of other associations (e.g., those dealing with a particular topic in psychiatry).<ref name=bylaws2011/><ref name=Statutes2011/> There are 72 scientific sections.<ref name=about/>
== Publications == The official publication of the association is ''[[World Psychiatry (journal)|World Psychiatry]].''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/tocrender.fcgi?journal=297&action=archive |title=Archive of “World Psychiatry” |website=PubMed Central |publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information, U.S. National Library of Medicine |accessdate=2009-06-18}}</ref> ''World Psychiatry'' and the association's official books are published by [[Wiley-Blackwell]].<ref name=publications>{{cite web |title=Latest Publications |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://www.wpanet.org/detail.php?section_id=10&content_id=658 |access-date=24 December 2016 }}</ref> WPA also self-publishes a quarterly newsletter on its website.<ref>{{cite web |title=WPA News: Past Issues |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://www.wpanet.org/detail.php?section_id=7&content_id=434 |access-date=26 December 2016 }}</ref>
Several WPA scientific sections have their own official journals and newsletters: ; Journals<ref name=JournalsVolumes>{{cite web |title=Journals & Volumes Produced by WPA Sections |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://www.wpanet.org/detail.php?section_id=10&content_id=423 |access-date=26 December 2016 }}</ref> : ''{{lang|la|Activitas Nervosa Superior}}'' (Psychiatric Electrophysiology Section)<ref>{{cite web |title=ANS: The Journal for Neurocognitive Research |website=Activitas Nervosa Superior |url=http://www.activitas.org/index.php/nervosa/index |access-date=26 December 2016 }}</ref> : ''Archives of Women's Mental Health'' (Women's Mental Health Section)<ref name=publications/><ref>{{cite web |title=Archives of women's mental health |website=NLM Catalog |publisher= National Center for Biotechnology Information, U.S. National Library of Medicine |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nlmcatalog/9815663 |access-date=26 December 2016 }}</ref> : ''[[History of Psychiatry (journal)|History of Psychiatry]]'' (History of Psychiatry Section) : ''{{lang|it|Idee in Psichiatria}}'' (Ecology, Psychiatry and Mental Health Section) : ''International Journal of Mental Health'' (Psychiatric Rehabilitation Section) : ''[[Journal of Affective Disorders]]'' (Affective Disorders Section) : ''Journal of Intellectual Disability Research'' (Psychiatry of Intellectual Disability Section) : ''[[The Journal of Mental Health Policy and Economics|Journal of Mental Health Policy and Economics]]'' (Mental Health Economics Section) : ''[[Personality and Mental Health]]'' (Personality Disorders Section) : ''Psychiatry in General Practice'' (Rural Mental Health Section) : ''[[Psychopathology (journal)|Psychopathology]]'' (Classification, Diagnostic Assessment and Nomenclature Section; Clinical Psychopathology Section) : ''{{lang|es|Revista de Psicotrauma}}'' (Disaster Psychiatry Section) : ''{{lang|fr|Revue Francophone du Stress et du Trauma}}'' (Disaster Psychiatry Section) : ''[[Transcultural Psychiatry]]'' (Transcultural Psychiary Section) ; == Activities == The association has helped establish a [[code]] of [[Psychiatry#Professional ethics|professional ethics for psychiatrists]].<ref name=about/><ref>{{cite web |title=Madrid Declaration on Ethical Standards for Psychiatric Practice |date=21 September 2011 |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://wpanet.org/detail.php?section_id=5&content_id=48 }}</ref> The association has also looked into charges regarding [[History of Falun Gong|China's treatment of the Falun Gong]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Secretary General's summary of the proceedings and conclusions of the 2002 extraordinary and ordinary general assemblies |date=26 August 2002 |website=World Psychiatric Association |url=http://www.wpanet.org/detail.php?section_id=7&category_id=159&content_id=205 }}</ref>
